message.content:
We need to “extract” from the transactions only those rows that represent sales – that is, rows where the type is “Sale” – and then use the value in the “cost_amount” column (which reflects the cost incurred in delivering that sale). (Other types of transactions – such as purchases, expenses, fixed assets, etc. – do not directly go into computing the cost of goods sold on the income‐statement.) 

Step 1. In our table the brand “Sale…” rows are listed along with a “cost_amount”. (In our records each sale row has a “cost_amount” value and a “profit”; the “cost_amount” is the portion of the sale value that “cost” the company – the cost of goods sold.) 

Step 2. We list the sale transactions and “cost_amount” values as found in the table:

• Sale20240102003:    cost_amount = 50,000.0  
• Sale20240102004:    cost_amount = 150,000.0  
• Sale20240103006:    cost_amount = 80,000.0  
• Sale20240103007:    cost_amount = 100,000.0

• Sale20240118039:    cost_amount = 250,000.0

• Sale20240130056:    cost_amount = 100,000.0  
• Sale20240130057:    cost_amount = 60,000.0  

Step 3. Now we add all these cost_amounts together. (A running subtotal helps:)

• After first 2: 50,000 + 150,000 = 200,000  
• +80,000 = 280,000

• +60,000 = 5,240,000  

Step 4. The sum of the cost_amount across all sale transactions is 5,240,000.00

This sum represents the “Cost of Goods Sold” (COGS) – the cost of producing/delivering the products that were sold.

Thus, the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {"Cost of Goods Sold": "5240000.00"}
}
